awd_titl_txt: ECA-PGR: Developing multiplexed transcriptional regulation systems for plant genome reprogramming
awd_abstract_narration:
Altering gene regulation, also known as transcriptional reprogramming, is at the heart of plant development, reproduction, and responses to various stresses. Simultaneously reprogramming multiple, specific genes is desirable for studying gene function and expression, dissecting complex signaling networks, engineering metabolic pathways, and building synthetic switches and circuits. However, genetic tools that would allow biologists to turn multiple genes on and off in this way in plant cells are currently unavailable. This project develops these tools and will not only aid basic research in plant science, but also allow plant scientists to seek novel solutions to global challenges such as devastating plant diseases, economical bioenergy production, sustainable agriculture and response to climate change. 

This project applies recent technical advances in CRISPR plant genome engineering to build essential comprehensive genome reprogramming tools and demonstrate them in rice, an important crop. The specific aims of this project are to develop 1) an efficient multiplexed transcriptional activation system; 2) an efficient multiplexed transcriptional repression system; 3) a bidirectional multiplexed transcriptional regulation system; and 4) a CRISPR design tool within the software of the Integrated Genome Browser for transcriptional regulation in plants. The highly efficient plant transcriptional reprogramming systems and the design tool developed in this project will benefit the plant research community in advancing basic research and crop improvement. These easy-to-use, effective tool packages will be tested for sophisticated multigene, transcriptional reprogramming and made available to researchers at the public repository, Addgene. In addition, the project will provide cutting-edge training to a diverse group of students at various levels, including a postdoctoral scientist, two PhD students, and many undergraduate and high school students from diverse backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Altering gene regulation, known as transcriptional reprogramming, is at the heart of plant development, reproduction, and responses to various stresses. Simultaneous, targeted transcriptional reprogramming of multiple genes is desirable for studying gene function and expression, dissecting complex signaling networks, engineering metabolic pathways, as well as building synthetic switches and circuits. Genetic tools that can be used for efficient multigene transcriptional reprogramming in plants, however, are currently unavailable to plant biologists. Such tools will allow biologists to turn gene expression on and off on a large scale in plant cells. The development of these tools will not only aid basic research in plant science but also allow plant scientists to seek novel solutions to global challenges such as devastating plant diseases, economical bioenergy production, sustainable agriculture, and climate change. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: This project applies recent technical advances in CRISPR plant genome engineering to build essential comprehensive genome reprogramming tools and demonstrate them in rice and other plants. For efficient multiplexed transcriptional activation, we developed a CRISPR-Act3.0 as a potent CRISPR activation (CRISPRa) system for gene activation in plants. We deduced the general guidance on design guide RNAs to achieve potent gene activation. With CRISPR-Act3.0, we demonstrated the use of this technology for metabolic engineering and speeding up plant regeneration to obtain genome-edited plants. For efficient multiplexed transcriptional repression, we developed a suite of CRISPR tools for CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), based on Cas9, Cas12a, Cas12b, and Cas12j2 proteins. These different CRISPRi systems, due to their different target sequence preference and efficiency, allow for quantitative fine-tuning of gene expression in plants. We demonstrate the use of these CRISPRi systems in Arabidopsis and rice, supporting their wide applications in many plant species. Hence, multiple easy-to-use effective vector tools have been developed for sophisticated multigene transcriptional reprogramming in plants. These tools have been made available to researchers at the public repository, Addgene. This project resulted in 47 publications and three patent applications.

BROADER IMPACTS: The developed genome engineering tools will have numerous applications for plant genetics and genomics, which is evidenced by the participation of many plant scientists who are applying these novel tools in their ongoing research focused on crop plants such as rice, maize, wheat, setaria, lettuce, tomato, carrot, poplar, citrus, and strawberry. Training future scientists, especially from under-represented minority groups, has been a core mission of this research project. This proposal has provided cutting-edge training to a diverse body of students at multiple levels, including five postdoctoral scientists, four PhD students, and many undergraduate students at the University of Maryland (UMD). The project also provided hands-on internship training to 12 mostly minority STEM high school interns in two local high schools, Montgomery Blair High School (MBHS) and Eleanor Roosevelt High School (ERHS). ERHS enrolls 60-62% African Americans and 9-12% Hispanics. We also participated in other community outreach activities which include the PI’s participation in the Annual Environmental Science Speaker Series Program in Northeast High School in Maryland and our plant genome engineering educational booth during the annual Maryland Day event, which brings >80,000 people to the University of Maryland campus.
